column4: how do I add a new directory to a system-wide PATH in Ubuntu? I guess its not via ld.so.conf...
echo 'PATH="$PATH:/new/dir"' >> ~/.bashrc  # and log out and log back in
thats not system-wide
don't know why you'd want to make this system wide .. but /etc/bash.bashrc or /etc/profile
adding the same thing to /etc/profile seems to have no effect
did you log out and log back in?
yep
perhaps export is needed. and put it in /etc/bash.bashrc
I have 'PATH="$PATH:/home/ut3server/ut3-dedicated/Binaries"' at the end of my /etc/profile
echo 'export PATH="$PATH:/home/ut3server/ut3-dedicated/Binaries"' | sudo tee -a /etc/bash.bashrc
must be in a typo in there somewhere, says: -bash: export PATH="$PATH:/home/ut3server/ut3-dedicated/Binaries": No such file or directory
the directory does in fact exist, copy pasted the path and cded to it
you missing an echo from the command.
echo 'export PATH="$PATH:/home/ut3server/ut3-dedicated/Binaries"' | sudo tee -a /etc/bash.bashrc
thanks, that worked, you have me quite puzzled tho, the resulting appending line from your command looked the same as the one I simply copy/pasted into the config
so where exactly did you get this error then?  i assumed it was at the shell?
I had that error on the shell upon relogon
let's see the output of this then.   tail -n 1 /etc/bash.bashrc
nevermind, copy/pasting your exact suggestion did work, I am just puzzled why copypasting it into bash.bashrc didnt
and I mean copypasting the export command with path
you could have had quotes around the text you pasted - a side effect of some irc clients .. or just some general syntax error
